Award.AwardTitle: A Modular Capability for Community Modeling of Flares, Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) and their Interplanetary Impacts
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant is for partial support of a project selected and funded under the 2012 NASA-NSF partnership for Space Weather Modeling Collaborations. It is a collaborative effort between NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (GSFC) and University of Michigan. The objective is to develop a new generation of numerical simulation codes and tools for community-wide investigation of Solar flares, coronal mass ejections (CME), and solar energetic particles (SEP) to test theories of solar eruptions against observed events and work towards a predictive capability. The Modular Solar Eruptions Capability (MSEC) to be developed will consist of a set of interchangeable modules and libraries, including an observables and a training library, which will enable the user to model a complete solar eruption event, from energy build-up by flux emergence to space weather impact at Earth. The new capability builds on recent advances by the proposing team in understanding the physics of flares and CMEs and in modeling space weather. The team has developed some of the leading theories for solar activity and has delivered some of the most widely used space weather models that is currently available to the community. Specific defining objectives for the development of the MSEC include: utilizing a two-temperature model for the solar plasma and incorporating the necessary physics important for the energy state of the solar atmosphere; utilizing a new phenomenological model for the solar wind-based Alfv√©n-wave acceleration and dissipation; exploring the physical connection between the upper convection zone and the solar corona by coupling two state-of-the-art models of flux emergence with the global model of the solar corona, thereby addressing the issue of energy build-up and CME initiation in a self-consistent manner. The team forms a strong collaboration between internationally recognized experts in basic solar and heliospheric theory, in the modeling and data analysis of observed events, and in computational physics.

When completed, the MSEC will be delivered to the Community Coordinated Modeling Center (CCMC) for access by the scientific community and eventual transition to use for operational space weather forecasting. The state-of-the-art simulation codes and tools comprising the final MSEC constitute an innovative and potentially transformative capability that will be used by the whole community to attack the solar eruption problem. While the team will pursue an exciting science program that uses the new models to attack the core science problems in solar eruptions, it is envisioned that the bulk of the science results ultimately will be obtained by the outside community. The results of this effort will help advance our understanding and modeling of solar eruptions, which are high priority national space weather needs. Educational components of the project include the participation of postdocs and graduate students. The collaboration builds on and greatly strengthens a longstanding partnership between the partners. Amongst others, this will provide the opportunity for students of University of Michigan to work with leading NASA scientists and have access to the unique resources at GSFC, a national facility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the help of this grant we developed a second-generation Space Weather Modeling Strategic Capability that enables both our Team and, more importantly, the space science community to test theories of solar eruptions against observed events, and to work toward a predictive capability. We have been fully successful in delivering to the Community Coordinated Modeling Center (CCMC) this second-generation capability for modeling CMEs/eruptive flares. This model is truly pioneering in that, to our knowledge, it is the first CCMC model that is designed for exploratory science. It is now being used by the community.

For modeling the global background through which solar eruptive events (SEEs) and all space weather propagate, we have developed AWSoM (the Alfven Wave Solar-atmosphere Model). AWSoM uses MHD to simulate the complete chromosphere-to-planets system using, to our knowledge, the most comprehensive physics that has ever been applied to this problem. AWSoM includes separate electron and ion temperatures and separate parallel and perpendicular temperatures for the ions. It solves detailed energy equations for both plasma and waves including collisional and collisionless field-aligned thermal conduction and the most sophisticated treatment, to date, of coronal heating by Alfven wave turbulence. Furthermore, we have extended AWSoM to include a multifluid capability, since He in particular can play a crucial role in both the Alfven wave turbulence and the solar wind dynamics. AWSoM defines the state-of-art. AWSoM has been delivered to the CCMC and is updated on a regular basis as new capabilities are added. It is used routinely for production runs to determine the state of the heliosphere given the observed solar photospheric magnetic field and an assumed Alfven wave flux as input. 

AWSoM includes the capability of high-resolution studies of observed active regions through use of its high-performance adaptive mesh refinement (AMR) capability. The problem of understanding SEEs requires modeling a broad range of critical scales, from the global scale of many solar radii, to the two orders of magnitude smaller scale of an active region, to the two orders of magnitude smaller scale of a filament channel, which of course must be clearly distinguishable from the dissipation scale. Even with AMR, a major challenge with using AWSoM in high-resolution mode for space weather prediction or for comprehensive exploration of multiple CME models is the spatial resolution required to calculate the transition region evolution accurately. developed an innovative model that finally solves the transition region problem, AWSoM-R (Real-time). Instead of using a prohibitively large 3D mesh for the transition region, we use a set of 1D field lines that connect each grid point of the bottom boundary of the corona/heliosphere of AWSoM to the top boundary of the chromosphere. AWSoM then solves the set of 1D mass, momentum, and energy equations along those field lines. AWSoM-R delivers a speedup of roughly 200 relative to AWSoM, allowing for both real-time modeling and for exploratory science that requires multiple simulations with varying parameters. AWSoM-R has also been delivered to the CCMC for community use. 

For simulating observed eruptions and advancing both understanding and prediction, we have developed EEGG, (Eruptive Event Generator using the Gibson-Low fluxrope model). EEGGL allows the user to select an active region from an observed magnetogram of a Carrington rotation, then select the polarity inversion line where the eruption is observed to originate and insert a Gibson-Low (G-L) fluxrope to produce eruption. The various parameters of the G-L model are constructed by an automated script to match the observed CME source region and speed. The user can change parameters, for example, helicity, initial orientation, etc. to experiment with the properties of the resulting eruption. It should be emphasized that EEGGL is a major advance and has the potential for transforming how the community performs both exploratory and space weather science. It is the first full-MHD CME model at the CCMC and will allow the community to address a vast range of important issues such as the dependence of BZ at 1 AU on the assumed structure of the filament channel and the observed photosphere and corona. We expect that the community will come up with a great number of creative uses for the extended EEG. 

We have also developed and delivered to the CCMC two models for determining the critically important particle radiation from CMEs/flares. We developed FLAMPA to calculate shock-accelerated SEP ion fluxes and spectra. FLAMPA solves the diffusive shock-acceleration equation along a selected field line connecting the observer to the Sun. FLAMPA calculates the SEP propagation to 1 AU and the spectrum, using the time-dependent parameters for the shock and magnetic field obtained from the MHD simulation. We have extended FLAMPA to a multiple field line version, M-FLAMPA, which has also been delivered to the CCMC.
